edu.mhs.compsys.processing

Class BinaryImageProcessor

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.mhs.compsys.processing.BinaryImageProcessor

  • public class BinaryImageProcessor
extends java.lang.Object
    A utility class that provides methods for working with BinaryImages.

    • Method Detail

      • erode

        public static BinaryImage erode(BinaryImage input)
        From wikipedia: Erosion is one of two fundamental operations (the other being dilation) in Morphological image processing from which all other morphological operations are based. It was originally defined for binary images, later being extended to grayscale images, and subsequently to complete lattices.
        Parameters:
        input - binaryImage to be eroded.
        Returns:
        A new binary image that is the eroded version of the given image

      • erode

        public static BinaryImage erode(BinaryImage input,
                boolean box)
        From wikipedia: Erosion is one of two fundamental operations (the other being dilation) in Morphological image processing from which all other morphological operations are based. It was originally defined for binary images, later being extended to grayscale images, and subsequently to complete lattices.
        Parameters:
        input - binaryImage to be eroded.
        Returns:
        A new binary image that is the eroded version of the given image

      • dilate

        public static BinaryImage dilate(BinaryImage input)
        From Wikipedia: Dilation is one of the basic operations in mathematical morphology. Originally developed for binary images, it has been expanded first to grayscale images, and then to complete lattices. The dilation operation usually uses a structuring element for probing and expanding the shapes contained in the input image
        Parameters:
        input - binary image that needs to be dilated
        Returns:
        A binary image that has been dilated

      • dilate

        public static BinaryImage dilate(BinaryImage input,
                 boolean box)
        From Wikipedia: Dilation is one of the basic operations in mathematical morphology. Originally developed for binary images, it has been expanded first to grayscale images, and then to complete lattices. The dilation operation usually uses a structuring element for probing and expanding the shapes contained in the input image
        Parameters:
        input - binary image that needs to be dilated
        Returns:
        A binary image that has been dilated

      • open

        public static BinaryImage open(BinaryImage input)
        A morphological operation that involves first dilating the input then eroding it. It results in a BinaryImage that has had small 'blemishes' removed.
        Parameters:
        input -
        Returns:
        The image opened with a structure of 't'.

      • open

        public static BinaryImage open(BinaryImage input,
               boolean box)
        A morphological operation that involves first eroding then dilating the input. It results in a BinaryImage that has had small 'blemishes' removed.
        Parameters:
        input -
        Returns:
        The image opened with the given structure.

      • close

        public static BinaryImage close(BinaryImage input)
        A morphological operation that involves first eroding then dilating the input. This results in an images that has its 'holes' filled up.
        Parameters:
        input -
        Returns:
        The image closed with a structure of 't'.

      • close

        public static BinaryImage close(BinaryImage input,
                boolean box)
        A morphological operation that involves first dilating the input then eroding it. This results in an images that has its 'holes' filled up.
        Parameters:
        input -
        Returns:
        The image closed with a given structure.

      • fromDiff

        public static BinaryImage fromDiff(java.awt.image.BufferedImage in1,
                   java.awt.image.BufferedImage in2)
        This function takes two BufferedImages and returns a BinaryImage. Each pixel that is true has been changed. Each pixel that is false is the same in both images.
        Parameters:
        in1 - The first BufferedImage
        in2 - The second BufferedImage
        Returns:
        The difference between the two images.

      • toImage

        public static java.awt.image.BufferedImage toImage(BinaryImage input)
        This method takes a binaryImage and converts it into a BufferedImage to save or print or show on a GUI.
        Parameters:
        input - BinaryImage
        Returns:
        BufferedImage of the BinaryImage
